content:
ASIA

BoJ is reportedly to review the allocation of ETF purchases according to reports. Separately, Twitter sources noted the BoJ may consider dropping JGB buying operation dates release, while the BoJ may allow slight JGB yield curve steepening and were said to see higher super long yields having a favourable effect. (Nikkei/Twitter)

PBoC is said to ease bank capital rule to promote lending, while reports noted the change would mean a different way of calculating banks' capital adequacy ratio which would reduce required capital buffers. (Newswires)

China's President Xi said trade wars should be rejected and that there will be no winners from trade wars, while President Xi added that China's doors are wide open. (Newswires)
 

UK

UK Trade Minister Fox said UK had constructive meetings in the US on trade and that they cannot allow the opportunity for a bilateral agreement with the US to pass by, while Fox added that the UK wants as much trade access without tying hands. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Hammond said UK does not have legal basis to extend Article 50, even if it wanted to. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -6.147M vs. Exp. -2.331M (Prev. 5.836M). (Newswires)

US Department of Energy finalised a rule to expedite approval for small-scale natgas exports. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia halted oil shipments through Bab-el-Mandeb strait near Yemen after 2 vessels were attacked by Houthi rebels. (Newswires)
 

US

There were initial reports that Europe was said to have made concessions to US President Trump in trade talks in which they agreed to lower industrial tariffs and import more US soybeans. This was then confirmed in a joint press conference in which US President Trump stated that the US is launching a phase of close friendship with the EU and that they agreed to work on zero tariffs, barriers and subsidies on non-auto industrial goods. Furthermore, Trump stated EU has agreed to buy more US soybeans and that they will resolve steel and aluminium tariffs, while Trump also stated there will be no new tariffs against EU after parties agreed to trade negotiations and will work together to reform the WTO. (Newswires)

US Senators earlier introduced a bipartisan bill to delay auto tariffs until a study has been completed, while there were also prior reports that some of US President Trump advisers had expected auto-tariffs imposed this year. (Washington Post)

Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo said essence of NAFTA is trilateral and will continue to be trilateral, while he also stated that the three sides need to show flexibility to reach an agreement. In related news, Mexico’s Foreign Affairs Minister Videgaray said NAFTA Negotiations are at a very advanced stage but challenges still remain, while Canada’s Foreign Minister Freeland said a renewed NAFTA deal can be realised. (Newswires)

Notable Earnings
- Boeing Co (BA) Q2 Adj EPS USD 3.33 vs. Exp. USD 3.27, rev. USD 24.3bln vs. Exp. USD 24.04bln; raises rev. guidance.
- Facebook (FB) Q2 EPS USD 1.74 vs. Exp. USD 1.72, rev. USD 13.23bln vs. Exp. USD 13.36bln, MAUs and DAUs miss exp.
- Ford Motor Co (F) Q2 Adj EPS USD 0.27 vs. Exp. USD 0.31, revenue USD 38.92bln vs. Exp. USD 35.83bln; cuts 2018 EPS view.
- General Motors (GM) Q2 EPS USD 1.81 vs. Exp. USD 1.86, rev. USD 36.8bln vs. Exp. USD 36.73bln, cuts 2018 ADJ. EPS view.
- PayPal (PYPL) Q2 Adj EPS USD 0.58 vs. Exp. USD 0.57, rev. USD 3.86bln vs. Exp. USD 3.81bln; declares USD 10bln buyback.
- Qualcomm (QCOM) Q3 Adj EPS USD 1.01 vs. Exp. USD 0.71, rev. USD 5.6bln vs. Exp. USD 5.19bln; to terminate purchase of NXPI, announces USD 30bln share buybacks.
- Visa Inc (V) Q3 Adj EPS USD 1.20 vs. Exp. USD 1.09, rev. USD 5.2bln vs. Exp. USD 5.09bln.


MARKET RECAP

US equity futures grinded higher today with the Emini 500 reaching highs of 2834.5 as trade war concerns alleviated following positive comments from US President Trump and EU’s Juncker, who are optimistic on a deal between the two blocs. Along with news that Senate was introducing a bipartisan bill to prevent Trump applying auto tariffs under national security rules propelled the ES to the highest since February. As the second busiest day of earnings season kicked off, Boeing (BA) beat on top and bottom line, however it forecast its FY core EPS below Wall St. expectations, this resulted in the DJI underperforming the US today as the name accounts for 10% of the index. Auto names were hit after earnings from General Motors (GM), shares fell by the most since 2011 today whose EPS missed expectations and they cut their FY Adj. EPS forecast to $6 from $6.41 due to higher steel and aluminium costs. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) also reported figures where its adjusted EBIT came in lower than expectations, FCAU also cut its revenue guidance. The combination of the two added pressure to its competitors, with the likes of Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) who closed the EU session with losses of 2.7%, Ford (F) were also hit ahead of their earnings tonight at 21:15 BST / 16:15 EST. Coca Cola (KO) led the Dow after its numbers beat on both ends as its diet drinks sales increased, however it did note revenues were hit with a 15% headwind after the refranchising of its company owned bottling operations. AT&T (T) reported AMC on Tuesday and the name hit a 6 year low as its revenue missed estimates and were also lower by 2% on a y/y basis, however it forecasts its 2018 adjusted EPS in the high $3.50 range, above expectations of $3.44. SPX +0.91% at 2846, NDX +1.38% at 7508, DJI +0.68% at 25414.

The US Treasury sold USD 36bln of 5-year notes in a decent sale which saw a stop-through of 1bps, and better participation from indirects. The curve was mixed on Wednesday, with 2-year yields printing fresh near-decade highs ahead of next week’s FOMC. US new home sales data garnered little price action, with traders opting to keep their powder dry ahead of the Trump/Juncker meeting. The curve continued to flatten, with 2s30s narrow by around 3bps at settlement, 2s5s flatter by slightly less than that, while other major curve spread were narrower modestly. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 3 ticks higher at 119-21.

(Early) US MARKET WRAP – 25 July 2018: Europe said to make concessions on trade with the US
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flatter, crude up, dollar down.
* REAR-VIEW:  Trump/Juncker make positive comments on trade pre-meeting; US Senators have introduced a bipartisan bill to delay auto tariffs until a study has been completed; EIA reports big crude draw, US new home sales plunge.
* COMING-UP: AMC earnings from QCOM, V, PYPL, F; Thursday’s ECB rate decision, Thursday BMO earnings from AMZN, INTC, MA, CMCSA.

* TRADE: Before US President Trump and EU’s Juncker met to discuss trade, Trump said he was hopeful that something can be worked out on a fair trade deal with Europe, adding that the US wants, at minimum, reciprocal trade with its Allies, and he was expecting something positive on trade at the meeting. Juncker said that the EU and the US are allies, not enemies, and that the two will focus on reducing tariffs not increasing them. At the same time, it was reported that US Senators have introduced a bipartisan bill to delay auto tariffs until a study has been completed. The positivity from Trump/Juncker combined with the headline from Senate helped stoke risk sentiment, pushing the USD to lows and buoying the ES to highs. According to early reports, Europe reportedly made concessions to Trump in trade talks, agreeing to lower industrial tariffs and import more US soybeans. The two leaders will give a joint press conference in aftermarket trade. Regarding China, Trump on Wednesday tweeted 'The US was being nice on China, until now' adding to the US-Sino tensions. In the context of the one-time aid programme for farmers the Trump administration authorised on Tuesday, a Chinese state planner announced that China will provide policy support for workers affected by structural adjustment and trade frictions.

* BREXIT: UK Trade Minister Fox said the UK has had constructive meetings in the US on trade and cannot allow the opportunity for a bilateral agreement with the UK, noting the UK wants as much trade access without tying hands.  

* NAFTA: Mexico’s Foreign Affairs Minister Videgaray said negotiations are at a very advanced stage but challenges still remain. Canada’s Freeland said the renewed NAFTA deal can be realised. Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo noted the essence of NAFTA is trilateral and will continue to be trilateral and that the three sides need to show flexibility to reach an agreement, going against Trump’s proposal of bilateral negotiations.

* US NEW HOME SALES plunged by 5.3% in June, more than the expected drop of 2.8%, with house sales in the South suffering the most. Analysts at Wells Fargo suggest that affordability is holding back sales given the higher mortgage rates and the elevated house prices, noting ‘rising rates appear to be causing buyers to shift to less expensive homes or put off buying altogether’. As for outlook, Wells Fargo said ‘housing simply is not going to strengthen as much as had been hoped’.

* FUTURES: US equity futures have grinded higher today with the Emini 500 reaching highs of 2834.5 as trade war concerns alleviated following positive comments from US President Trump and EU’s Juncker, who are optimistic on a deal between the two blocs. Along with news that Senate was introducing a bipartisan bill to prevent Trump applying auto tariffs under national security rules propelled the ES to the highest since February.

*EARNINGS: As the second busiest day of earnings season kicked off, Boeing (BA) beat on top and bottom line, however it forecast its FY core EPS below Wall St. expectations, this resulted in the DJI underperforming the US today as the name accounts for 10% of the index. Auto names were hit after earnings from General Motors (GM), shares fell by the most since 2011 today whose EPS missed expectations and they cut their FY Adj. EPS forecast to $6 from $6.41 due to higher steel and aluminium costs. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) also reported figures where its adjusted EBIT came in lower than expectations, FCAU also cut its revenue guidance. The combination of the two added pressure to its competitors, with the likes of Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) who closed the EU session with losses of 2.7%, Ford (F) were also hit ahead of their earnings tonight at 21:15 BST / 16:15 EST. Coca Cola (KO) led the Dow after its numbers beat on both ends as its diet drinks sales increased, however it did note revenues were hit with a 15% headwind after the refranchising of its company owned bottling operations. AT&T (T) reported AMC on Tuesday and the name hit a 6 year low as its revenue missed estimates and were also lower by 2% on a y/y basis, however it forecasts its 2018 adjusted EPS in the high $3.50 range, above expectations of $3.44.

*M&A: Today marks the deadline for the deal with Qualcomm (QCOM) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) where QCOM is to acquire NXPI for USD 44bln, however QCOM said they would abandon the deal if they cannot win approval from Chinese regulators by 23:59 EST on Wednesday July 25th, and the two are still yet to hear from the anti-trust regulators in China, and QCOM was reported to be considering buybacks in that event.

* WTI (U8) SETTLES 78 CENTS HIGHER AT $69.30; BRENT (U8) SETTLES 49 CENTS HIGHER AT $73.93. Weekly inventory data showed a larger-than-expected drawdown for headline crude stocks (6.15mln vs exp 2.33mln), Cushing saw a draw of 1.13mln; the products also drew down, with distillate stocks lower by 100k, and gasoline stocks lower by 2.33mln. Headline crude stocks in the US are now at the lowest seasonal level since 2014, and 67mln barrels above its 10-year average, according to Reuters; US distillate stockpiles are at their lowest in more than a decade. Elsewhere, Russia raised its 2018 oil output forecast to 11.02mln BPD, a new 30-year high. In Libya, the Zawia oil terminal is poised to exit its force majeure shortly and a shipment has been booked for later in the month, according to Argus, and the Amal oil field flow is said to fall to 8K BPD on power cuts. Finally, Iranian events continue to warrant attention: the revolutionary guard on Wednesday said that US threats on oil can be easily answered, while the foreign ministry said Iran says will respond in kind if US tries to block oil exports.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (U8) SETTLE 3 TICKS HIGHER AT 119-21. The US Treasury sold USD 36bln of 5-year notes in a decent sale which saw a stop-through of 1bps, and better participation from indirects. The curve was mixed on Wednesday, with 2-year yields printing fresh near-decade highs ahead of next week’s FOMC. US new home sales data garnered little price action, with traders opting to keep their powder dry ahead of the Trump/Juncker meeting. The curve continued to flatten, with 2s30s narrow by around 3bps at settlement, 2s5s flatter by slightly less than that, while other major curve spread were narrower modestly.  

* USD: Positive comments from Trump and Juncker regarding trade, along with news that senators are looking to tie Trump’s hands on auto tariffs helped push the USD lower, amid a constructive risk tone. The DXY remains beneath 94.40 as we head into Asia, with the nearest technical support is seen around 94.207-200 and this area incorporates Monday’s session low.

* JPY: The yen advanced against the buck, falling through 111.00 to lows above 110.67 after Nikkei reported that the BoJ will review its allocation of ETF purchases at its policy meeting next week, in keeping with the recent sources stories which suggest that the central bank may make some tweaks to its policy settings after the disappointing run of inflation of late. However, some (Goldman Sachs, for instance) do not believe changes will be forthcoming.

* CAD: The Loonie has emerged as top G10 performer and is retesting highs vs its US rival not seen since the BoC hiked rates and delivered an upbeat assessment that warrants further tightening depending on incoming data. USDCAD filled bids through 1.3140-30 and 1.3115-00 to trade sub 1.3090, and USDCAD saw further downside in the afternoon post-Trump/Juncker initial comments.

* NZD, EUR, GBP, JPY, CHF: All around 0.2-0.25% ahead vs the Greenback, with the Kiwi maintaining 0.6800+ status after a NZ trade data-related wobble overnight (surprise deficit), but perhaps hampered by the proximity of a mega (1.75 bn) option expiry at the strike running off on Thursday. The single currency is attempting to climb over 1.1700 again and has at least one eye on the ECB meeting tomorrow.

* GBP: Cable remains choppy above 1.3150 amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty and with the 20 DMA at 1.3175 capping further recovery gains towards 1.3200.

* AUD: Relatively deflated all day in wake of sub-consensus headline CPI data for Q2, but managing to stay above 0.7400 vs the USD and still trading in lock-step with Yuan (or at least swings in US-China trade sentiment). Note, the CNY and CNH both unwound more losses vs the Dollar to circa 6.7500-7600 vs the latest 6.8000 PBoC mid-point fix and recent lows approaching 6.8500.

* EM: Another decent day all round, but especially for the Lira amidst reports that the US Pastor imprisoned due to terrorist link accusations has been moved from jail to house arrest, while the Peso got a welcome boost from significantly stronger than forecast Mexican retail sales, alongside improving NAFTA deal prospects. USDTRY down to 4.8200 and USDMXN 18.7000 approximately at best.

Daily FX Wrap: Buck slips ahead of Trump-Juncker auto tariff trade-off
content:
USD

Some minor range breaks and net Dollar weakness ahead of the US-EU summit to discuss trade relations (Trump vs Juncker showdown kicks off at 18.30BST, and latter is due to address the press at 21.00BST), with the DXY down below 94.400 at one stage having topped out above 94.500 yet again. To recap, nearest technical support is seen around 94.207-200 and this area incorporates Monday’s session low.

CAD

The Loonie has emerged as top G10 performer and is retesting highs vs its US rival not seen since the BoC hiked rates and delivered an upbeat assessment that warrants further tightening depending on incoming data. Usd/Cad filled bids through 1.3140-30 and 1.3115-00 to trade under 1.3090 vs the aforementioned post-July 11 policy meeting low circa 1.3060.

NZD/EUR/GBP/JPY/CHF

All around 0.2-0.25% ahead vs the Greenback, with the Kiwi maintaining 0.6800+ status after a NZ trade data-related wobble overnight (surprise deficit), but perhaps hampered by the proximity of a mega (1.75 bn) option expiry at the strike running off on Thursday. The single currency is attempting to climb over 1.1700 again, but half-heartedly awaiting any developments/agreement from the White House summit and with at least one eye on the ECB meeting tomorrow. Cable remains choppy around 1.3150 amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty and with the 20 DMA at 1.3175 capping further recovery gains towards 1.3200, while Usd/Jpy is finding 111.00 a tough level to break on the downside, but appears on track to close below its 20 DMA (111.44-50) and a key Fib (111.25), which would be bearish from a chart perspective. The Franc is still in a Summer stupor and hemmed into a 0.9945-05 range, while pivoting 1.1600 vs the Eur.

AUD

Relatively deflated all day in wake of sub-consensus headline CPI data for Q2, but managing to stay above 0.7400 vs the Usd and still trading in lock-step with Yuan (or at least swings in US-China trade sentiment). Note, the Cny and Cnh both unwound more losses vs the Dollar to circa 6.7500-7600 vs the latest 6.8000 PBoC mid-point fix and recent lows approaching 6.8500.

EM  

Another decent day all round, but especially for the Lira amidst reports that the US Pastor imprisoned due to terrorist link accusations has been moved from jail to house arrest, while the Peso got a welcome boost from significantly stronger than forecast Mexican retail sales, alongside improving NAFTA deal prospects. Usd/Try down to 4.8200 and Usd/Mxn 18.7000 approximately at best.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 25th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities are relatively mixed (Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%) as focus remains on earnings seasone
  • Limited movement in FX markets at DXY continues to pivot around the 94.500. AUD lags peers following domestic CPI data overnight
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US New Home Sales, DoEs, supply from the US, Juncker to meet with Trump and a slew of large cap earnings

ASIA

Asian stocks were mixed with macro drivers on the light side and after the region failed to sustain the momentum from the positive US close where earnings dominated focus. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was negative amid broad weakness across the index aside from the commodity-related sectors, while materials names and continued strength in Japanese banks kept the Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) afloat. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were varied as Hong Kong was led higher by oil names including Sinopec which expects its highest H1 profit since 2013 and with the mainland less decisive following a liquidity drain by the PBoC, while the KOSPI (-0.3%) was dampened on earnings including LG Display. Finally, 10yr JGBs gained overnight and broke above this week’s highs in a continuation of its recent rebound and with the BoJ present in the market for JPY 650bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end, while reports also noted BoJ watchers viewed the central bank was unlikely to tighten policy before October and some even believed there were prospects of looser policy.

BoJ is seen by experts as unlikely to tighten monetary policy before October despite speculation the bank may act at its upcoming meeting due to the impact of its ultra-loose policy, while reports also noted that some believe further easing is on table to support inflation. (Nikkei)

Chinese state planner announces that China will provide policy support for workers affected by structural adjustment and trade frictions. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 60bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8040 (Prev. 6.7891); weakest fix since 28th June 2017.

Australian CPI (Q2) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)

Australian CPI (Q2) Y/Y 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 1.9%)

Australian Trimmed Mean CPI (Q2) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

Australian Trimmed Mean CPI (Q2) Y/Y 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 1.9%)

New Zealand Trade Balance (NZD)(Jun) M/M -113M vs. Exp. 200M (Prev. 294M, Rev. 208.0M). (Newswires)

New Zealand Trade Balance (NZD)(Jun) Y/Y -4030M vs. Exp. -3681M (Prev. -3598M, Rev. -3680M)

New Zealand Exports (NZD)(Jun) 4.91B vs. Exp. 5.06B (Prev. 5.42B, Rev. 5.35B)

New Zealand Imports (NZD)(Jun) 5.02B vs. Exp. 4.92B (Prev. 5.12B, Rev. 5.15B)

EU/UK/US

US President Trump tweeted that the EU is coming to Washington to negotiate a trade deal and he has an idea for both US and EU to drop all tariffs, barriers and subsidies which would be called Free Market & Fair Trade, while Trump added he hopes they do it and the US is ready but thinks they won’t. (Twitter)

EU's Juncker says do not need fresh tariffs, but instead calm the situation. (Newswires)

EU's Malmstrom states that the EU is planning tariffs of USD 20bln on US goods, adding that the EU still hopes to find a solution with the US. (Newswires)

EU Budget Commissioner Oettinger says EU would respond in kind if US levies fresh tariffs but adds that the EU is ready to discuss tariff cuts for all products. (Newswires)

Mexico incoming Foreign Minister says believes NAFTA agreement is possible relatively soon, also comments that US President Trump stated in letter that the 2 countries should increase cooperation. (Newswires)

US President Trump can be heard on tape discussing with his attorney Michael Cohen how to acquire the rights to former Playboy model Karen McDougal’s story about her alleged affair with Trump, in a recording obtained by CNN. (Guardian)

German Ifo Business Climate New (Jul) 101.7 vs. Exp. 101.6 (Prev. 101.8)

German Ifo Expectations New (Jul) 98.2 vs. Exp. 98.1 (Prev. 98.6, Rev. 98.5)

German Ifo Current Conditions New (Jul) 105.3 vs. Exp. 104.8 (Prev. 105.1, Rev. 105.2)

EQUITIES

European equities are relatively mixed (Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%) as focus remain on earnings season. The Healthcare sector was lifted by GSK’s (+1.5%) earnings, while tech names underperform amid weak earnings from STMicroelectronics (-4.1%) who currently rest at the foot of the CAC 40. France’s LVMH (+1.7%) rose to the top of the index post-earnings, dragging up the likes of Kering (+2.6%). Ageas (4.2%) shares are lifted by reports Hong Kong’s Fosun is weighing a USD 10bln takeover of the company. A few US heavyweights are expected to report earnings today; Boeing (12.30 BST), UPS (12:45BST), Facebook, Visa and PayPal (21:05BST).

FX

DXY - Minimal movement in Dollar pairings, as the index continues to pivot around the 94.500 axis looking for more direction that might emanate from US-EU trade talks later rather than data in the form of new home sales. However, some signs of a shift in sentiment overnight and potential change in the recent trend of further Yuan depreciation post-PBoC Usd/Cny fixing, as both the on-shore and off-shore units hold above 6.8000.

AUD - The marginal G10 underperformer amidst another loss of momentum above 0.7400 vs its US counterpart and 1.0900 against the NZD on slightly softer than forecast Aussie Q2 inflation, albeit with headline y/y CPI back into the RBA’s 2-3% target range for the first time in almost 3 years. Conversely, the Kiwi has recovered from a sub-0.6800 dip following an unexpected June trade deficit, albeit only just.

CAD/CHF/GBP/EUR - All mildly firmer vs the Usd, but rangebound, with the Loonie sitting near the base of a 1.3165-25 band, Franc at the low end of 0.9945-10 parameters and Cable holding around 1.3150 after an uptick in UK mortgage apps, and ahead of CBI trades. Meanwhile, not a lot of reaction to slightly better than anticipated German Ifo survey readings or Eurozone money supply from the single currency that is probing 1.1700 again, and remains capped ahead of 0.8900 vs the Pound, with more focus on tomorrow’s ECB policy meeting and any further policy guidance (even though unlikely given QE and rate signals delivered only last month).

JPY - Usd/Jpy meandering between 111.05-40 and still delicately poised around a 111.25 Fib, while latest reports on the end of month BoJ meeting suggest no change in policy likely until October, and in stark contract to sources perhaps even more easing rather than any hawkish tweak (per so called ‘experts’).

EM - Aside from the aforementioned Cny and Cnh counter-moves, other EMs, including the Try, have recouped more losses vs the Greenback, with the Mxn aided by latest positive NAFTA noises to rebound further from 20.000 and through 19.000.

FIXED INCOME

A tepid Bobl launch based on all the usual metrics used to gauge the strength of an auction has undermined German bond futures, with the 5 year contract retesting lows just below parity and the 10 year Bund paring gains to single digits vs almost 20 ticks at best. Meanwhile, Gilts have slipped back into negative territory in wake of another better than expected UK CBI survey, and this time distributive trades to a marginal new LIFFE low of 123.20 (-11 ticks). Elsewhere, US Treasuries are back down from overnight peaks ahead of more supply ($36 bn 5 year notes and $18 bn 2 year FRNs) and some secondary data, but perhaps more importantly the Trump-Juncker tariff summit.  

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.2%) trades marginally softer with Brent (+0.9%) higher after breaching USD 74.00/bbl to the upside. Last night’s API Crude inventories printed a larger than expected drawdown (-3.160M vs. Exp. -2.300M), tempering oversupply concerns that have weighed on markets recently. Of note, an IMF report commented on the steep inflation rise in Venezuela (while sanction risks remain), which has subsequently limited its ability to boost oil output. (Of note: Venezuelan oil production fell to a new 30-year low of 1.5mln BPD in June). Traders will be watching today’s DoE Crude inventories which are expected to show a draw of 2.331M barrels.

Gold (+0.5%) gradually crawls higher as USD strength eases. Copper is flat while traders are eyeing the latest developments at the world’s largest copper mine, BHP’s Escondida in Chile. The Anglo-Australian miner had made its final offer with the union regarding an increase in wages, markets await further updates.

US API weekly crude stocks (20 Jul) -3.160M vs. Exp. -2.300M (Prev. +0.629M). (Newswires)

Libya’s Zawia oil terminal is poised to exit its force majeure shortly and a shipment has been booked for later in the month. (Argus News)

Bunds: extending recovery gains above 162.00 handle
content: The 10 year German benchmark is building a firmer platform above new mtd lows set yesterday within an early 162.30-41 Eurex range vs Tuesday’s 162.28 close, but rather unconvincingly and in relatively thin volumes so far. The recovery is in keeping with some retracement in US Treasuries off their recent lows as the curve continues to re-flatten, but the overall trend remains bearish at present, and with more supply forthcoming yields are unlikely to concede too much more ground without a major catalyst or fundamental change of sentiment. Technically, 162.42-44 represents near term resistance and a 38.2% Fib retracement of last Friday’s downturn, according to market contacts, while a chart gap is seen down to 162.27 ahead of support at 162.23. Ahead, Germany’s Ifo may provide further impetus along with the aforementioned issuance via a new 0% Bobl in Eur4 bn.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

25th July 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks were mixed with macro drivers on the light side and after the region failed to sustain the momentum from the positive US close where earnings dominated focus. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was negative amid broad weakness across the index aside from the commodity-related sectors, while materials names and continued strength in Japanese banks kept the Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) afloat. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were varied as Hong Kong was led higher by oil names including Sinopec which expects its highest H1 profit since 2013 and with the mainland less decisive following a liquidity drain by the PBoC, while the KOSPI (-0.2%) was dampened on earnings including LG Display.

FTSE

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. affirms Q2 preliminary results. Q2 revenues in equity sales and trade were down 6% at EUR 540mln. Q2 net profit EUR 401mln, pre-tax profit EUR 711mln, Q2 provisions for credit loss EUR 95mln. Q2 investment bank pre-tax profit EUR 475mln, private and commercial bank pre-tax profit EUR 262mln. Q2 assets management pre-tax profit EUR 93mln. Q2 adj. costs down 1% y/y to EUR 5.6bln.  CEO says Co. is headed in the right direction on costs and balance sheet quality is strong. Co.’s primary target is to generate a post-tax return on average tangible equity of over 4% in 2018. Co. is committed to reduce adj. costs for 2018 to EUR 23bln.

Linde (LIN GY) – H1 revenue EUR 8.64bln vs. Prev. EUR 8.935bln. Co. confirms 2018 outlook. Co. says completion of merger with Praxair (PX) remains planned for H2. Co. is said to plan a reintegration of Gist:Platow and to end its sale effort. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 25th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks were mixed with macro drivers on the light side and after the region failed to sustain the momentum from the positive US close
  • In FX, the greenback was rangebound, AUD/USD pressured following softer than expected headline CPI, CNH stabilized despite another weak reference rate setting by the PBoC
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German IFO, US New Home Sales, DoEs, supply from Germany and the US, Juncker to meet with Trump and a slew of large cap earnings

ASIA

Asian stocks were mixed with macro drivers on the light side and after the region failed to sustain the momentum from the positive US close where earnings dominated focus. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was negative amid broad weakness across the index aside from the commodity-related sectors, while materials names and continued strength in Japanese banks kept the Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) afloat. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were varied as Hong Kong was led higher by oil names including Sinopec which expects its highest H1 profit since 2013 and with the mainland less decisive following a liquidity drain by the PBoC, while the KOSPI (-0.2%) was dampened on earnings including LG Display. Finally, 10yr JGBs gained overnight and broke above this week’s highs in a continuation of its recent rebound and with the BoJ present in the market for JPY 650bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end, while reports also noted BoJ watchers viewed the central bank was unlikely to tighten policy before October and some even believed there were prospects of looser policy.

BoJ is seen by experts as unlikely to tighten monetary policy before October despite speculation the bank may act at its upcoming meeting due to the impact of its ultra-loose policy, while reports also noted that some believe further easing is on table to support inflation. (Nikkei)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 60bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8040 (Prev. 6.7891); weakest fix since 28th June 2017.
 

UK/EU

US President Trump tweeted that the EU is coming to Washington to negotiate a trade deal and he has an idea for both US and EU to drop all tariffs, barriers and subsidies which would be called Free Market & Fair Trade, while Trump added he hopes they do it and the US is ready but thinks they won’t. (Twitter)

The Association of German Chambers of Commerce and Industry chief said US tariffs could cost Germany EUR 5bln. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, the greenback was rangebound and so too were its major counterparts in which EUR/USD faltered ahead of the 1.1700 handle and with GBP/USD stuck around 1.3150. Antipodeans were the main movers with AUD/USD pressured following softer than expected headline CPI which analysts noted provides scope for the RBA to remain on hold well into next year but with downside stemmed as it was the 1st time in 10 quarters headline inflation moved to within the RBA’s 2%-3% target range. Elsewhere, NZD/USD was also data-driven and eventually gave up the 0.6800 handle after a surprise Trade Deficit and miss on Exports, while CNH stabilized despite another weak reference rate setting by the PBoC.

Australian CPI (Q2) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
Australian CPI (Q2) Y/Y 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 1.9%)
Australian Trimmed Mean CPI (Q2) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)
Australian Trimmed Mean CPI (Q2) Y/Y 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 1.9%)

New Zealand Trade Balance (NZD)(Jun) M/M -113M vs. Exp. 200M (Prev. 294M, Rev. 208.0M). (Newswires)
New Zealand Trade Balance (NZD)(Jun) Y/Y -4030M vs. Exp. -3681M (Prev. -3598M, Rev. -3680M)
New Zealand Exports (NZD)(Jun) 4.91B vs. Exp. 5.06B (Prev. 5.42B, Rev. 5.35B)
New Zealand Imports (NZD)(Jun) 5.02B vs. Exp. 4.92B (Prev. 5.12B, Rev. 5.15B)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful with WTI crude futures only marginally supported overnight following a wider than expected drawdown in headline API crude inventories, as prices took a breather from the prior session’s gains in which it briefly tested USD 69.00/bbl while Brent outperformed but with upside capped by resistance at USD 74.00/bbl. Elsewhere, gold was kept range-bound by a flat greenback, while copper was also sideways alongside a muted tone across the complex and an indecisive risk tone in mainland China.

US API weekly crude stocks (20 Jul) -3.160M vs. Exp. -2.300M (Prev. +0.629M). (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said we’ll see what happens with Iran but is open to a ‘real deal’, while there were also comments from US Defence Secretary Mattis stated that it is time for Iran to show responsibility and was also said to be concerned about military in the South China Sea. (Newswires)


US

Treasuries ended Tuesday’s session mixed and mostly flat. Most of the action was concentrated in the long end of the curve where yields were lower by c.2bps at settlement. 2s30s and 5s30s narrowed by c.2bps, 2s10s and 5s10s narrowed by c.1bps. The US Treasury sold $35bln in 2yr notes at a high-yield of 2.657%, the highest since July 2008. The bid-to-cover came in at 2.92x, the highest since January. Indirects took the largest share since February whilst directs were awarded the smallest portion since March. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 2+ ticks higher at 119-180.

US President Trump has told farmers affected by retaliatory tariffs to be patient as they will benefit eventually, while USDA Secretary Perdue confirmed reports that the US is authorising a one-time programme of up to USD 12bln in aid to assist farmers that suffered from tariffs which will kick in on Labor Day and includes direct payment, food purchase and trade promotion programmes. (Newswires)

US House voted to permanently repeal Obamacare medical device tax. (Newswires)

US House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Brady said he wants to lock in tax cuts for the middle class and that he expects the panel to vote on a new tax bill in September. (Newswires)

Mexico incoming Foreign Minister believes NAFTA agreement is possible relatively soon and commented that US President Trump stated in a letter that the 2 countries should increase cooperation. (Newswires)

US President Trump can be heard on tape discussing with his attorney Michael Cohen how to acquire the rights to former Playboy model Karen McDougal’s story about her alleged affair with Trump, in a recording obtained by CNN. (Guardian)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mixed as lack of macro drivers keeps focus on earnings
content:
Asia stocks are mixed with macro drivers on the light side and after the region failed to sustain the momentum from the positive US close where earnings dominated focus. ASX 200 (-0.2%) is negative amid broad weakness across the index aside from the commodity related sectors, while materials names and continued strength in Japanese banks have kept the Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) afloat. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) are also varied as Hong Kong is led higher by oil names including Sinopec which expects its highest H1 profit since 2013 and with the mainland less decisive following a liquidity drain by the PBoC, while the KOSPI (-0.1%) is dampened on earnings including LG Display which posted a larger than expected net loss.

In FX markets, the greenback is rangebound and so too are its major counterparts with EUR/USD faltering ahead of the 1.1700 handle and GBP/USD stuck around 1.3150. Antipodeans were the main movers with AUD/USD pressured following softer than expected headline Q2 CPI Y/Y at 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.2%, which analysts note provides scope for the RBA to remain on hold well into next year but with downside stemmed as it was the 1st time in 10 quarters inflation moved to within the RBA’s 2%-3% target range. Elsewhere, NZD/USD was also data-driven with the pair eventually giving up the 0.6800 handle after a surprise Trade Deficit and miss on Exports, while CNH has stabilized despite another weak reference rate setting by the PBoC.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are slightly higher overnight as prices eye an attempt on this week’s highs, while the BoJ are also in the market for JPY 650bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end and with its buying amounts kept unchanged.
